Award.AwardTitle: SNM: Scalable Continuous Production of Aligned Carbon Nanotube and Nanoporous Membranes

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective: The overall objective of this project is to develop scalable methods for fabricating vertically aligned carbon nanotube and nanoporous membranes for applications in analytical separation and water purification. This project will result in a reliable pilot process for the manufacture of such membranes utilizing large area mechanically robust films and the systematic characterization of the performance of these membranes. The potential impact of this research is transformative - the materials, methods and knowledge developed can enable a broad spectrum of technologies from water purification to energy generation and health care, with profound societal impacts.

Intellectual Merits: The intellectual merits stem from the following: (1) Investigation of materials science and process engineering to enable the production of vertically aligned nanostructured membranes; (2) Rigorous experimental studies of nano-confined transport. This project will accomplish a long sought goal in the reliable production of large-area membranes with controlled, aligned nanoporosity. Characterization of the structure-property-processing relationships in these systems will constitute new and valuable practical manufacturing know-how.

Broader Impacts: The broader impacts of the project are: (1) Integration of research and education through new curriculum development for undergraduate and graduate courses; (2) K-12 outreach activities in Science Fair and Science Pathways programs; (3) A focus on recruitment of under-represented groups; (4) Summer research opportunities for undergraduates and industrial internships for students. Additionally, there will be a strong technical impact due to the close collaboration with industry and the commitment to the development of an industrially relevant process.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated the design and utilization of novel materials and methods for controlling the orientation of nanostructures in thin films. Specifically, the work focused on scalable processes for producing thin polymer films with uniformly-sized nanopores with controlled vertical orientation. Such films are desired for the production of next generation nanofiltration materials for water purification applications. The project examined block copolymers as well as mesophases produced by small molecules, including amphiphilic surfactants and discotic mesogens.

Work focused on the use of magnetic fields, and the use of physical confinement, as methods to control the orientation of self-assembled structures in polymer films over large areas. The project showed conclusively that both magnetic fields and physical confinement enable scalable processing with robust control over the orientation of the self-assembled structures produced. The project involved the design and construction of custom apparatus for executing the above described processes. One apparatus entailed a roll-to-roll system that permitted the passage of polymer materials through a high field magnet with a desired temperature profile applied. A second apparatus involved combined use of ultraviolet illumination and physical confinement to produce sub-micron thick films by polymerization after vertical alignment of the nanostructures in the system.

Overall, the project resulted in robust demonstrations of (1) scalable processing of polymer films with controlled vertical orientation of cylindrical channels; (2) fabrication of membranes with high charge and size-based selectivity; (3) creation of single-crystal textures in self-assembled soft materials. It is anticipated that the methods and materials developed here can be leveraged to produce thin films with vertically oriented nanopores in an industrially relevant manner, for use as membranes, or as masks for pattern transfer lithography.

This project has supported the training of 3 doctoral students, 1 postdoctoral researcher, and provided summer and academic year research opportunities for several undergraduate students and one high school student.

 


Last Modified: 03/22/2018
Modified by: Chinedum Osuji

Images (1 of )
  • Transmission electron microscopy of a polymer film (cross-sectional view) shows the uniform vertical alignment of self-assembled columnar structures produced by soft-confinement processing.
    Xunda Feng
    Public Domain
    Chinedum Osuji
    Vertically Aligned Structures by TEM
  • Self-assembled columnar structures are vertically aligned in a thin film by confinement between appropriate surfaces. Crosslinking of the material results in a polymeric film with uniform vertically oriented features.
    Xunda Feng
    Public Domain
    Chinedum Osuji
    Alignment by Soft Confinement
  • Aligned nanopores in a polymer membrane absorb various dye molecules in a size and charge specific manner. Species larger than about 1.5 nm or negatively charged species are rejected from the membrane.
    Xunda Feng
    Public Domain
    Chinedum Osuji
    Selective Absorption Based on Molecular Size and Charge

Specifically, the work focused on scalable processes for producing thin polymer films with uniformly-sized nanopores with controlled vertical orientation. Such films are desired for the production of next generation nanofiltration materials for water purification applications. The project examined block copolymers as well as mesophases produced by small molecules, including amphiphilic surfactants and discotic mesogens. Work focused on the use of magnetic fields, and the use of physical confinement, as methods to control the orientation of self-assembled structures in polymer films over large areas. The project showed conclusively that both magnetic fields and physical confinement enable scalable processing with robust control over the orientation of the self-assembled structures produced. The project involved the design and construction of custom apparatus for executing the above described processes. One apparatus entailed a roll-to-roll system that permitted the passage of polymer materials through a high field magnet with a desired temperature profile applied. A second apparatus involved combined use of ultraviolet illumination and physical confinement to produce sub-micron thick films by polymerization after vertical alignment of the nanostructures in the system. Overall, the project resulted in robust demonstrations of (1) scalable processing of polymer films with controlled vertical orientation of cylindrical channels; (2) fabrication of membranes with high charge and size-based selectivity; (3) creation of single-crystal textures in self-assembled soft materials.
